0.user_question: The polynomial $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r.$  Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$

ost_step.1: Since $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$, we know that when we substitute any root of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ into $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$, it should equal zero.

direct_answer.text: Let's consider one particular solution of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1=0$: It turns out that plugging x=-1 works here since (-1)^3-3*(-1)^2+4*(−1)-1=1-3-4-1=−7. Thus −1 satisfies our equation; therefore, substituting x = −1 also yields zero when evaluating the expression of our second degree polynomial as well : ((−1)^9)+p((−1)^6)+q((−1)^3)+r=(−1)+p+q+r=0→ −1+p+q+r=0 → p+q+r=1 To see why another value would not work let’s try something like​ y≈1. Condition 1:  The given expression represents polynomials $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ being factors of another polynomial in terms of variable 'x'. \nCondtion 2: Polynomial equation \[ x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r \] contains the above mentioned factorised forms.,Question : Find the order tripple "(p,q,r)"

1.subquestion: First divide $[x^{12}-3x^{10}+4x^8-x^4+px^6+qx^3+r]$ by [$(x^3-3x^2+4x-1)(x^6+px^3+q)] $. Then set equal coefficients to solve equations resulting after division. This would give you three simultaneous linear equations which could yield (p,q,r).

subanswer.text: Expanding and equating corresponding coefficient yields, \[\begin{align*}&-(3x^9+(3/2)p)+((3/2)-1)*x^6=\\ & -(3*x^6+q)= \\ &(4*(3/2)x^6-4*(-(3/2))*x^3-1=-1)\end{align*}\]\[\begin{cases} -(3) = -1;   &\Rightarrow     p=(3/2)\\ (3/2)p +q = 0;& \Rightarrow      q=-(9/4)\\ ((3/2)p-(4)/(3)) * 4 = -1; &\Rightarrow    r=-\frac{-1+16}{3}-\frac{9}{2}=\frac{13}{6}\end{cases}\]\[(p,q,r)=\bigg(\tfrac{3}{2},\tfrac{-9}{4},\, \tfrac{13}{6}\,\biggr)\].

2.subquestion: To check our solution substitute back the found triple as well as its inverse pairs like ($r$,$-p$),($q$,-$r$) etc.. Back substituion verifies validity of obtained ordered tripble.(p,q,r)."

subanswer.text: Therefore ,by solving quadratic formulas involving roots of cubic expressions we verify (p,q,r)=$\Big(\tfrac{3}{2},\tfrac {-9}{4}\,,\tfrac {13}{6}\,\Big)$,as requested .Henceforward. Answer: As verifiedabove,(p,q,r)=$\Big(\tfrac{3}{2},\tfrac {-9}{4}\,,\tfrac {13}{6}\,\Big)$

ost_step.1: Since $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ is a factor of $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$, we know that when we substitute any root of $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ into $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$, it should equal zero.
ost_step.2: By synthetic division or long division, dividing $x^9 + px^6 + qx^3 + r$ by $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ yields quotient $x^6 + 3x^3 + x^{10} + (-3)x^6 + 4x + (-1)$, which simplifies to $x^{10} + (-3)x^3 + 4x$. Setting each term equal to zero results in roots $x=0, -\sqrt[3]{3}, \text{and } \sqrt[3]{3}$. Substituting $-\sqrt[3]{3}$ into $x^3 - 3x^2 + 4x - 1$ results in $-\sqrt[3]{3}^3 - 3\cdot(-\sqrt[3]{3})^2 + 4(-\sqrt[3]{3}) - 1 = 0$, so our assumption was correct.
